item.title: Our Team
item.dc:creator: qb4htu
item.content:encoded:
The Real Team

College Real Talk was founded by college students dissatisfied with the amount of information and support available for making college decisions. Founded May 2020, amidst the coronavirus pandemic, College Real Talk was meant to be a way to help in a way we can, to alleviate some of the high stress of planning your future, which was then harder than ever. 

We asked current high school and college age students how their college application experience was, and found that students primarily looked online for help when applying to colleges, but that less than 14% of students had used the largest college forum site then available and even less found it helpful. The opinion was that the world seemed to care about the grades, percentages, and numbers, but not about providing any qualitative info about what it's like being at a college. Our research also found that about 68.9% of students were rather unconfident in their knowledge on financial aid, an important part of choosing a higher education and making it possible. Our team also found that community college was undervalued and stigmatized, and wanted to present non-four year schools as institutions of value by explaining when and how they could actually be the best and smartest option. Everyone at College Real Talk has been there- we care and want to help. 

So let's sit down for a Real Talk! and get to know each other.

Kamil Rahhali     -Founder-

A rising fourth year at Georgia Tech, Kamil is studying biomedical engineering and public policy; as an engineering student, he can relate to all of the suffering involved in getting into college- and out. Kamil wishes he had people tell him about high school internships, lab work, and what to look for when choosing a college. He also hates beating around the bush, so hopes this site can be the guidance counselor he wishes he had. Kamil's likes to eat, read, and game when he has free time* and writes food reviews sometimes. What you do with your time makes you you, and it's the greatest hope of this site that it can help you love the time you have.

Footnote: *never

Daniel Sanchez     -Yale Student-

Hello students. My name is Daniel Sanchez, and I am a professional Yale student. I graduated high school with high honors and was an esteemed member of the National Honor Academy. At Yale, I spend my time being an Ivy League student and love to study. It is my personal belief that everyone should pursue the highest education they can. Being at Yale has helped me become smarter, more liberal, and vegan! I hope this site can help you follow in my great footsteps.

College Real Talk for life! XD XD XD

Btw did I mention I go to yale? xd

heyo my name is anthony. I am a recipient of the ramsey scholarship at Weehawken High School so I know what I am talking about. As you see right now the world is in turmoil, but honestly that is because of the democrats. If we all just rallied around our Trump we would have already beaten this kung flu. Anyways remember to vote for Trump 2020!

item.title: College Life
item.dc:creator: qb4htu
item.content:encoded:
If you want to know where you can find your best college life, you need to know what kind of college life schools offer, and what that means for you.
Other sites might offer information about college sports rankings, acceptance rates, average SAT scores, which matter, but only so much. We want a place where you can know the life styles and culture, where you can imagine what living at this college might be like and whether it works for you.

The College Life information is sourced from current students, alumni, and maybe even some faculty, and meant to show the good, bad, and ugly. Let's Real Talk.

item.title: Contact us!
item.dc:creator: qb4htu
item.content:encoded:
College Real Talk is made for college students, by college students

We mean it when we say we're here for you. Our mission is to set the footsteps we wish we had; you can help us make sure those footsteps fit those you want by sending us a message below.

Ask us anything! Any time! We usually don't bite!
Give us your RealTalk.

Nothing to see here.

item.title: Funding College
item.dc:creator: qb4htu
item.content:encoded:
Ways to Fund College

Federal Aid

FAFSA The FAFSA (Free Application for Federal Student Aid) is the form that you fill out every year during college to determine your how much federal financial aid you are eligible to receive. The FAFSA is completely free so there is no excuse in not filling out the FAFSA, unless of course you do not want financial aid. EVERYONE SHOULD FILL OUT THE FAFSA.  Click on the button above to learn more! CSS The CSS (College Scholarship Service) profile is another form that you fill out to determine your financial aid eligibility. It is similar to the FAFSA, however, the main difference from the FAFSA is the CSS is used for universities to gauge how much non-federal financial aid you need. Generally, it is recommended to fill out both the CSS and the FAFSA to maximize financial aid.  Click on the button above to learn more!

Non-Federal Aid

School Aid School Aid is the grants and scholarships that are provided by the university to which you were admitted to. Basically, think of these scholarships as a gift or an incentive for you as a student to attend a certain college. Obviously, these scholarships are only applicable to the school that gave it to you in the first place.  Click on the button above to learn more! State Aid State Aid is financial aid that you get from your state government and is separate from federal aid, which comes from the national government. You can receive state aid on top of federal aid, which is why it's a great idea to fill out your state's aid application form and apply to in-state schools! State aid is only available for residents of that state, and is easy to fill out after the FAFSA. Click on the button above to learn more! Outside Scholarships Outside Scholarships are monetary awards provided by organizations outside of your school and federal aid. These scholarships are usually provided by certain NGOs, companies, generous rich people, or anyone else who is just willing to donate money directly to students.  Click on the button above to learn more!

item.title: Test
item.dc:creator: qb4htu

item.title: About us
item.dc:creator: qb4htu
item.content:encoded:
So, Real Talk

Figuring out what to do with your future is tough. As a kid, you think you know some things and know there's a Costco®'s Isle worth of things you don't. We've been there, done that - and are here to help.

Your guidance counselor may be telling you to apply to nearby four year schools. Nobody talks much about why Community College might be a smart move and we're sure you've never even heard of Trade School. All you know about College is that it's expensive, some are more respected than others, and you're under a lot of pressure to attend the best school you can get into. If you're not in the top 1% of students, you may end up applying to your dream school and a few local universities.

Do you know what the campus culture is like? Do the professors care about the students? Are there a lot of parties? Are the buildings well kept? Do Freshmen have to dorm? How will you get around? Can you keep proper diet and exercise?

Do you know if the school offers what you want and need? How competitive are the academics? Is the curriculum actually what I want to learn for my Major? How are classes graded? Does the school care about mental health / disabilities?

We made this site to help people make informed decisions about their future- I mean, you have your whole life ahead of you! Make the best decisions for YOU, get knowledgeable about schools, and go live YOUR best life.

item.title: FAFSA
item.dc:creator: qb4htu
item.content:encoded:
WHAT IS THE FAFSA?

The Free Application for Federal Student Aid (FAFSA) is the government's way of saying, "Yeah, we know college is ridiculously expensive and the commodification of education is burdening students and their families- here's some money". Like the name implies, it's a free application where you fill in your personal and financial information to help the government decide how much money you need from them to help pay for college.  The application is split up into six sections and will probably take a good sit down to fill out. The form is split into six sections, shown on the buttons below.  Click on the section you want to know more about to jump to that part in our walkthrough. Student Demographics School Selection Dependency Status Parent Demographics Financial Information Sign and Submit Once you fill out the FAFSA, the Department of Education will use your financial and familial information to find out how much aid you can get. Big parts of this aid comes in the form of subsidized and unsubsidized federal loans. You want these federal loans! They're where the money's at: Subsidized federal loans are the best because interest will not accrue while you are in school. What this means is that you'll pay less overall. Subsidization is need based, so be sure to fill out your FAFSA accurately if you need the money. Unsubsidized federal loans are another type of loan that are not dependent on your financial status for receiving. Interest adds up for these unsubsidized loans from the date you take them on, so be sure to be on top of making interest payments! Federal loans in general tend to have nicer interest rates, but be sure to be aware of the rate and total money you will owe over time! You might feel confused or intimidated about filling out a long form with all of your social and financial information. Real Talk- we've been there too, and we want to make it easier for you! We've provided a quick overview and walkthrough of the FAFSA form process so you can speed through it, no bumps, no confusion!

FAFSA WALKTHROUGH

Student Demographics: "Who are you?" - FAFSA The entirety of the FAFSA's about filling out your personal information. The first section is pretty straight forward; enter what the left hand of the form is asking for into the right hand, where the red censor bars are blotting out my personal info. Note the "Help and Hints" given by the FAFSA here, specifically to make sure you have no typos and that you don't use any crazy symbols in what you type. The FAFSA is really all about answering these basic questions without making any mistakes. You can say no to certain parts- if you don't have a license, you obviously won't need to provide a license number. Not having a license is not a problem when applying to the FAFSa, it's just a form of ID that's easy for them to use. If you are NOT a U.S. citizen, you'll need to say you are an "eligible noncitizen" to apply to the FAFSA. To qualify under this definition, you need to be a U.S. permanent resident, refugee, asylum granted status, parolee, Cuban-Haitian Entrant, T-Visa holder, victim of human trafficking, resident of Palau, Marshall Islands, or Micronesia, or Canadian-born Native American. If you don't fit into these categories, filling out the FAFSA can qualify you for financial aid from your state or school. Find out what's available for you- the FAFSA can still be worth your time. You won't be able to get federal aid though : When the FAFSA asks you if you're registered with the Selective Srvice System (draft), make sure you say yes! Anyone registered as male will need to say yes to this question to qualify for FAFSA aid, as of July 2020. Work-study is something you definitely want to say yes to if you need more money. The FAFSA will hook you up with a part time job at your school specifically to help you pay for your schooling. Fill out the information here as accurately as you can. The degree of schooling completed by your parents can affect some school and state aid on a need-based basis.  Drug Conviction here refers to any drug possession or dealing conviction that is currently on your record and of a conviction made after you were the age of 18.  If you do have a drug conviction on your record, you should still fill out the FAFSA- you will be ineligible for federal aid, but states and schools still use the information from your FAFSA to get you the money you need. This section appears if you stated that you attended high school. It should be pretty easy to fill out. The point of this section is to verify your education; you need a high school diploma, GED, or equivalent to receive federal and most state aid. School Selection: Just tell the FAFSA what school you're gonna use the money for. This part's pretty short. Your "Housing Plans" shouldn't affect the amount of oney you get from FAFSA - but if you state that you're living with family (not paying rent), you may not be eligible for some types of aid. The federal school code is an ID that colleges have. You can search it up so you don't have to type out the whole name of your school exactly as FAFSA recognizes it. You can easily find a school's federal code via web search or by downloading the Excel spreadsheet at this site. Dependency Status: How do you get that bread? Who takes care of you? Are you on your own? Are you taking care of other people? If you're struggling to get that bread for any reason, the FAFSA wants to help you out. If you have any children or work in the U.S. Armed Forces, you'll get some extra money to help you out. Similarly, the less support you've had and have, the more aid you can get.  Under the FAFSA, you will be labeled a dependent unless both of your parents are deceased or if you were in foster care. Living on your own doesn't make you an independent (and qualify you for more aid) until you're over 24 years old. Please don't put yourself at risk to get any financial aid. Homelessness for students is a real issue, and colleges often have systems for making their studies work out. Don't choose to be homeless to save money though, for what I'm hoping are obvious reasons. I'm sad I have to say it; you'd think people get it. I know you do. If your household size and number of people in your house going to college is larger, you will get more aid. When the FAFSA says household size they mean the number of mouths you're feeding with your money. Parent Demographics: Similar to what you had to put in for Student Demographics- the government wants to know who your guardians are, where they are, and how much bread they rake in.  This section is asking about your parent demographics though, and you'll only have to fill this out if you are a dependent, for the dependent(s) you have. Financial Information: This is where the real meat is. Get some help from a guardian to find out how much money your family's pulling, and make sure it's inputted right. The Financial Information page can be tricky, which is why transferring your tax info from the IRS is the quickest and safest way to go.  You'll need to click the "Link to IRS" button and use your FSA ID to link the IRS and FAFSA info. Get access to the federal income tax return you want to use and enter the information from there exactly as it appears into the IRS site. Then click the button to transfer your tax info into FAFSA, and check to make sure the info is transferred.  The information you need should automatically be filled up, but make sure your read through what was inputted with your guardian(s).  Some people have problems where tax info isn't properly transferred, so be ready to fill out everything manually. Remember that you only pay taxes if you make over $12,200 in a year. Little bits of cash income that you might make from baby sitting or doing chores don't need to be disclosed here! A Cooperative Education Program, usually called a co-op, are a type of full time work that students can do while attending school. Co-ops can be offered by a school or applied to like any regular job. Once you get a co-op, you can often register the co-op with your college to get college credit for your work experience while earning some real pay!  Co-ops are usually longer term than single semesters (which internships can be), and often take up the time of two semesters.  These co-ops can be offered as a 6 month period of employment, or can be split up into two semester long halves, where you will be able to take classes for a semester in between your two semesters of co-op work. Don't report anything you're not asked to, kids. The government wants to take your money and keep your money- it's on you to get some back. The less additional income you disclose, the more FAFSA aid you'll get.  If you don't have too many personal assets, you won't have to worry about a lot of these final questions. If you do though, feel free to skip them when given the option to do so! The less Big Brother government knows about you, the better! Similarly, the less support you've had and have, the more aid you can get.\u00a0<\/p>","text_color":"#000000","typography_typography":"custom","typography_font_family":"Arial","typography_font_size":{"unit":"px","size":18,"sizes":[]},"_background_color":"#F0F0F0"},"elements":[],"widgetType":"text-editor"}],"isInner":true},{"id":"67a94d1","elType":"column","settings":{"_column_size":50,"_inline_size":null},"elements":[{"id":"92d6762","elType":"widget","settings":{"editor":"Under the FAFSA, you will be labeled a dependent <\/b>unless both of your parents are deceased or if you were in foster care. Living on your own doesn't make you an independent <\/b>(and qualify you for more aid) until you're over 24 years old. ","text_color":"#000000","typography_typography":"custom","typography_font_family":"Arial","typography_font_size":{"unit":"px","size":18,"sizes":[]},"_background_color":"#F0F0F0"},"elements":[],"widgetType":"text-editor"}],"isInner":true}],"isInner":true}],"isInner":false}],"isInner":false},{"id":"212285c","elType":"section","settings":[],"elements":[{"id":"796e7a6","elType":"column","settings":{"_column_size":100,"_inline_size":null},"elements":[{"id":"f1484bf","elType":"widget","settings":{"space":{"unit":"px","size":75,"sizes":[]}},"elements":[],"widgetType":"spacer"},{"id":"022330b","elType":"widget","settings":{"image":{"url":"https:\/\/www.collegerealtalk.com\/wp-content\/uploads\/2020\/07\/7-1.jpg","id":2274}},"elements":[],"widgetType":"image"},{"id":"e41468a","elType":"widget","settings":{"anchor":"parentdemographics"},"elements":[],"widgetType":"menu-anchor"},{"id":"90e5ed7","elType":"section","settings":{"structure":"20"},"elements":[{"id":"04d4cbe","elType":"column","settings":{"_column_size":50,"_inline_size":null},"elements":[{"id":"dfa40d0","elType":"widget","settings":{"editor":"

Please don't put yourself at risk to get any financial aid.<\/p>

Homelessness for students is a real issue, and colleges often have systems for making their studies work out. Don't choose to be homeless to save money though, for what I'm hoping are obvious reasons. I'm sad I have to say it; you'd think people get it. I know you do.<\/p>","text_color":"#000000","typography_typography":"custom","typography_font_family":"Arial","typography_font_size":{"unit":"px","size":18,"sizes":[]},"_background_color":"#F0F0F0"},"elements":[],"widgetType":"text-editor"}],"isInner":true},{"id":"593ba79","elType":"column","settings":{"_column_size":50,"_inline_size":null},"elements":[{"id":"368e156","elType":"widget","settings":{"editor":"

If your household size and number of people in your house going to college is larger, you will get more aid. When the FAFSA says household size<\/b>\u00a0they mean the number of mouths you're feeding with your money.<\/p>","text_color":"#000000","typography_typography":"custom","typography_font_family":"Arial","typography_font_size":{"unit":"px","size":18,"sizes":[]},"_background_color":"#F0F0F0"},"elements":[],"widgetType":"text-editor"}],"isInner":true}],"isInner":true}],"isInner":false}],"isInner":false},{"id":"9a48cf8","elType":"section","settings":[],"elements":[{"id":"9a8964f","elType":"column","settings":{"_column_size":100,"_inline_size":null},"elements":[{"id":"bb501d1","elType":"widget","settings":{"space":{"unit":"px","size":75,"sizes":[]}},"elements":[],"widgetType":"spacer"},{"id":"5446b72","elType":"widget","settings":{"editor":"

Parent Demographics: <\/b>Similar to what you had to put in for Student Demographics- the government wants to know who your guardians are, where they are, and how much bread they rake in.\u00a0<\/p>","typography_typography":"custom","typography_font_size":{"unit":"px","size":18,"sizes":[]},"text_color":"#000000","typography_font_family":"Arial"},"elements":[],"widgetType":"text-editor"},{"id":"aac2b75","elType":"widget","settings":{"image":{"url":"https:\/\/www.collegerealtalk.com\/wp-content\/uploads\/2020\/07\/8-1.jpg","id":2275}},"elements":[],"widgetType":"image"},{"id":"88f8191","elType":"widget","settings":{"image":{"url":"https:\/\/www.collegerealtalk.com\/wp-content\/uploads\/2020\/07\/9-1.jpg","id":2276}},"elements":[],"widgetType":"image"},{"id":"a0a9542","elType":"widget","settings":{"anchor":"financialinformation"},"elements":[],"widgetType":"menu-anchor"},{"id":"ee3b381","elType":"section","settings":[],"elements":[{"id":"38dca2c","elType":"column","settings":{"_column_size":100,"_inline_size":null},"elements":[{"id":"c46cea3","elType":"widget","settings":{"editor":"

This section is asking about your parent demographics though, and you'll only have to fill this out if you are a dependent, for the dependent(s) you have.<\/p>","text_color":"#000000","typography_typography":"custom","typography_font_family":"Arial","typography_font_size":{"unit":"px","size":18,"sizes":[]},"_background_color":"#F0F0F0"},"elements":[],"widgetType":"text-editor"}],"isInner":true}],"isInner":true},{"id":"707d347","elType":"widget","settings":{"space":{"unit":"px","size":75,"sizes":[]}},"elements":[],"widgetType":"spacer"},{"id":"7951eae","elType":"widget","settings":{"editor":"

Financial Information: <\/b>This is where the real meat is. Get some help from a guardian to find out how much money your family's pulling, and make sure it's inputted right.<\/p>","typography_typography":"custom","typography_font_size":{"unit":"px","size":18,"sizes":[]},"text_color":"#000000","typography_font_family":"Arial"},"elements":[],"widgetType":"text-editor"},{"id":"46f1036","elType":"widget","settings":{"image":{"url":"https:\/\/www.collegerealtalk.com\/wp-content\/uploads\/2020\/07\/10-1.jpg","id":2277}},"elements":[],"widgetType":"image"},{"id":"d599dec","elType":"section","settings":{"structure":"20"},"elements":[{"id":"c048965","elType":"column","settings":{"_column_size":50,"_inline_size":null},"elements":[{"id":"ca575a9","elType":"widget","settings":{"editor":"

The Financial Information page can be tricky, which is why transferring your tax info from the IRS<\/b>\u00a0is the quickest and safest way to go.\u00a0<\/p>

You'll need to click the \"Link to IRS\" button and use your FSA ID to link the IRS and FAFSA info. Get access to the federal income tax return you want to use and enter the information from there exactly as it appears into the IRS site. Then click the button to transfer your tax info into FAFSA, and check to make sure the info is transferred<\/b>.\u00a0<\/p>","text_color":"#000000","typography_typography":"custom","typography_font_family":"Arial","typography_font_size":{"unit":"px","size":18,"sizes":[]},"_background_color":"#F0F0F0"},"elements":[],"widgetType":"text-editor"}],"isInner":true},{"id":"46401ca","elType":"column","settings":{"_column_size":50,"_inline_size":null},"elements":[{"id":"3b6a276","elType":"widget","settings":{"editor":"

The information you need should automatically be filled up, but make sure your read through what was inputted with your guardian(s).\u00a0<\/p>

Some people have problems where tax info isn't properly transferred, so be ready to fill out everything manually.<\/p>","text_color":"#000000","typography_typography":"custom","typography_font_family":"Arial","typography_font_size":{"unit":"px","size":18,"sizes":[]},"_background_color":"#F0F0F0"},"elements":[],"widgetType":"text-editor"}],"isInner":true}],"isInner":true}],"isInner":false}],"isInner":false},{"id":"7b14b37","elType":"section","settings":[],"elements":[{"id":"f451603","elType":"column","settings":{"_column_size":100,"_inline_size":null},"elements":[{"id":"b08882f","elType":"widget","settings":{"space":{"unit":"px","size":75,"sizes":[]}},"elements":[],"widgetType":"spacer"},{"id":"b118cd7","elType":"widget","settings":{"image":{"url":"https:\/\/www.collegerealtalk.com\/wp-content\/uploads\/2020\/07\/11-1.jpg","id":2278}},"elements":[],"widgetType":"image"},{"id":"3638697","elType":"widget","settings":{"image":{"url":"https:\/\/www.collegerealtalk.com\/wp-content\/uploads\/2020\/07\/12-1.jpg","id":2279}},"elements":[],"widgetType":"image"}],"isInner":false}],"isInner":false},{"id":"4fc37b4","elType":"section","settings":[],"elements":[{"id":"1c6fed5","elType":"column","settings":{"_column_size":100,"_inline_size":null},"elements":[{"id":"6104f86","elType":"widget","settings":{"image":{"url":"https:\/\/www.collegerealtalk.com\/wp-content\/uploads\/2020\/07\/13-1.jpg","id":2280}},"elements":[],"widgetType":"image"}],"isInner":false}],"isInner":false},{"id":"7b6bc24","elType":"section","settings":[],"elements":[{"id":"73f5b7b","elType":"column","settings":{"_column_size":100,"_inline_size":null},"elements":[{"id":"c2bf3af","elType":"section","settings":{"structure":"20"},"elements":[{"id":"850c787","elType":"column","settings":{"_column_size":50,"_inline_size":null},"elements":[{"id":"6ff7c07","elType":"widget","settings":{"editor":"

Remember that you only pay taxes if you make over $12,200 in a year. Little bits of cash income that you might make from baby sitting or doing chores don't need to be disclosed here!<\/p>","text_color":"#000000","typography_typography":"custom","typography_font_family":"Arial","typography_font_size":{"unit":"px","size":18,"sizes":[]},"_background_color":"#F0F0F0"},"elements":[],"widgetType":"text-editor"}],"isInner":true},{"id":"d344e52","elType":"column","settings":{"_column_size":50,"_inline_size":null},"elements":[],"isInner":true}],"isInner":true},{"id":"fea43a7","elType":"widget","settings":{"space":{"unit":"px","size":75,"sizes":[]}},"elements":[],"widgetType":"spacer"}],"isInner":false}],"isInner":false},{"id":"a26fa38","elType":"section","settings":[],"elements":[{"id":"da42592","elType":"column","settings":{"_column_size":100,"_inline_size":null},"elements":[{"id":"67045e3","elType":"widget","settings":{"image":{"url":"https:\/\/www.collegerealtalk.com\/wp-content\/uploads\/2020\/07\/14-1.jpg","id":2281}},"elements":[],"widgetType":"image"},{"id":"47d5bac","elType":"section","settings":{"structure":"20"},"elements":[{"id":"33d0ed5","elType":"column","settings":{"_column_size":50,"_inline_size":null},"elements":[{"id":"7a30590","elType":"widget","settings":{"editor":"

A Cooperative Education Program<\/b>, usually called a co-op<\/b>, are a type of full time work that students can do while attending school. Co-ops can be offered by a school or applied to like any regular job. Once you get a co-op, you can often register the co-op with your college to get college credit for your work experience while earning some real pay!\u00a0<\/p>

\u00a0<\/p>","text_color":"#000000","typography_typography":"custom","typography_font_family":"Arial","typography_font_size":{"unit":"px","size":18,"sizes":[]},"_background_color":"#F0F0F0"},"elements":[],"widgetType":"text-editor"}],"isInner":true},{"id":"d198454","elType":"column","settings":{"_column_size":50,"_inline_size":null},"elements":[{"id":"07dae4a","elType":"widget","settings":{"editor":"

Co-ops are usually longer term than single semesters (which internships can be), and often take up the time of two semesters.\u00a0<\/p>

These co-ops can be offered as a 6 month period of employment, or can be split up into two semester long halves, where you will be able to take classes for a semester in between your two semesters of co-op work.<\/p>","text_color":"#000000","typography_typography":"custom","typography_font_family":"Arial","typography_font_size":{"unit":"px","size":18,"sizes":[]},"_background_color":"#F0F0F0"},"elements":[],"widgetType":"text-editor"}],"isInner":true}],"isInner":true},{"id":"204fd2d","elType":"widget","settings":{"space":{"unit":"px","size":75,"sizes":[]}},"elements":[],"widgetType":"spacer"}],"isInner":false}],"isInner":false},{"id":"0c108d4","elType":"section","settings":[],"elements":[{"id":"63094e5","elType":"column","settings":{"_column_size":100,"_inline_size":null},"elements":[{"id":"332770b","elType":"widget","settings":{"image":{"url":"https:\/\/www.collegerealtalk.com\/wp-content\/uploads\/2020\/07\/15-1.jpg","id":2282}},"elements":[],"widgetType":"image"},{"id":"8dd4bde","elType":"section","settings":{"structure":"20"},"elements":[{"id":"5ade25a","elType":"column","settings":{"_column_size":50,"_inline_size":null},"elements":[{"id":"cbfce61","elType":"widget","settings":{"editor":"

Don't report anything you're not asked to, kids. The government wants to take your money and keep your money- it's on you to get some back.<\/p>

The less additional income you disclose, the more FAFSA aid you'll get.\u00a0<\/p>","text_color":"#000000","typography_typography":"custom","typography_font_family":"Arial","typography_font_size":{"unit":"px","size":18,"sizes":[]},"_background_color":"#F0F0F0"},"elements":[],"widgetType":"text-editor"}],"isInner":true},{"id":"9dac049","elType":"column","settings":{"_column_size":50,"_inline_size":null},"elements":[{"id":"dfbca31","elType":"widget","settings":{"editor":"

If you don't have too many personal assets, you won't have to worry about a lot of these final questions. If you do though, feel free to skip them when given the option to do so! The less Big Brother government knows about you, the better!<\/p>","text_color":"#000000","typography_typography":"custom","typography_font_family":"Arial","typography_font_size":{"unit":"px","size":18,"sizes":[]},"_background_color":"#F0F0F0"},"elements":[],"widgetType":"text-editor"}],"isInner":true}],"isInner":true},{"id":"bb581c9","elType":"widget","settings":{"anchor":"signnsubmit"},"elements":[],"widgetType":"menu-anchor"},{"id":"4a9e102","elType":"section","settings":{"structure":"20"},"elements":[{"id":"31167c9","elType":"column","settings":{"_column_size":50,"_inline_size":null},"elements":[{"id":"26c15a5","elType":"widget","settings":{"editor":""},"elements":[],"widgetType":"text-editor"}],"isInner":true},{"id":"3a18488","elType":"column","settings":{"_column_size":50,"_inline_size":null},"elements":[{"id":"4a7ceaa","elType":"widget","settings":{"editor":""},"elements":[],"widgetType":"text-editor"}],"isInner":true}],"isInner":true}],"isInner":false}],"isInner":false},{"id":"9833a4b","elType":"section","settings":{"gap":"narrow","content_position":"middle","overflow":"hidden","structure":"60","margin":{"unit":"px","top":"-1","right":0,"bottom":"-1","left":0,"isLinked":true},"padding":{"unit":"px","top":"0","right":"0","bottom":"0","left":"0","isLinked":true}},"elements":[{"id":"2916648","elType":"column","settings":{"_column_size":16,"_inline_size":17.2890000000000014779288903810083866119384765625},"elements":[{"id":"50c8d9d","elType":"widget","settings":{"text":"Student item.title: School Aid
item.dc:creator: qb4htu
item.content:encoded:
WHAT IS SCHOOL AID?

Generally, when we are referring to School aid it is the money that is offered to you from your school directly. Therefore, this number will vary a lot because different schools offer different amounts of money. Today we will discuss the two main types of aid that a colleges usually provide to their students. These types are called Merit Scholarships and Need Based Scholarships. 

NOTE: NOT EVERY SCHOOL GIVES MERIT OR NEED BASED SCHOLARSHIPS

WHAT ARE MERIT BASED SCHOLARSHIPS?

Merit Scholarships are usually specified amounts of money given to students as grants meaning that they do not need to be paid back. Think of Merit Scholarships as an award that you have earned. In any given college, only a limited number of students receive Merit Scholarships so if you have received one that is very impressive! Merit Scholarships are usually determined in two different ways. They can either be solely grade based or holistic based.  Merit Scholarships are usually scholarships that schools give prior to your enrollment. Occasionally depending on your school these scholarships can also be obtained if you perform well during your college years. For example, certain schools offer a scholarship for students who make the Dean's list (an award for reaching a certain GPA in a semester). So if you did not receive a scholarship when you enrolled it is possible to eventually work hard and receive one. However, in the majority of cases merit scholarships are usually determined prior to your enrollment. 

GRADE BASED MERIT SCHOLARSHIPS (GBMS)

Grade based scholarships are usually the easiest to determine your eligibility in receiving them. The required scores that an applicant must hit are usually posted on the college's websites. Sometimes they also require that you are from a certain background, like for example a first generation student, before you qualify for the scholarship. Colleges will specify their requirements and usually they have just number requirements that they require to be hit. Take for example the "Presidential Scholarship" from NJCU (New Jersey City University). As you see above, for a full ride at NJCU all an applicant needs to hit is a 3.00 GPA and a 1270 SAT or 26 ACT score. Once you have hit those specified numbers you are basically guaranteed the scholarship if you are admitted to that college. However, sometimes colleges are not as open to telling their applicants what the specific numbers that they need to hit are. So it is important to first understand how your college operates. 

HOLISTIC BASED MERIT SCHOLARSHIPS (HBMS)

Holistic Based Merit Scholarships usually take into account other factors other than purely grades. It is important to understand that grades still matter, but they will not be the sole determiner in whether someone receives a scholarship or not. These similar to Grade Based Merit Scholarships are also usually determined prior to your enrollment. These scholarships are also usually listed on a college's website, but they usually give vague descriptions of what they want in an applicant. Unlike the Grade based scholarships sometimes these Holistic Scholarships require an additional application, but this is not always the case. There are also cases we have seen where these HBMS come in form of scholar programs. They require students to take extra classes and commit to certain projects in order to maintain the status of their scholarship. They are also frequently referred to as Honors Programs, but of course this differs from school to school. Sometimes colleges have a dedicated Honors program that has a required Grade cut-off, while some schools admit Honor Students through a holistic review. The Martin Luther King, Jr. Scholars Program at New York University is one example of such programs.  As you see above, this scholarship is treated more like a program where you are required to take certain classes and participate in certain events. However, when we view it from our broke college student perspectives this is an awesome program, but an even more awesome full ride for your 4 years New York University. 

NOTE: The examples we shown were just one sample of each type of scholarship. Just because in our example the MLK scholarship offered more money does not mean that HBMS offer more than GBMS. These numbers and requirements are specific to these schools only.

WHAT ARE NEED BASED SCHOLARSHIPS?

Need Based Scholarships are scholarships that schools give to certain students based on the information provided to the schools from when the students fill out the FAFSA or CSS. Basically, when you fill out one of these financial aid forms that you provide is processed and given to the schools that you are applying for. The schools then shift through the processed forms and determine which students, whom they have admitted, need additional financial aid the most. It is also common to see states or other organizations give these scholarships to students, but these scholarships are obviously not given to you from your school. Universities that offer extensive Need Based Scholarships usually outline very clearly their requirements in receiving these scholarships. It is also very common for an applicant to provide further proof to finalize these types of scholarships. These scholarships are less in one's control and really just up to a student's personal life situation and income. The income brackets that usually receive these scholarships are extremely close to poverty lines, and therefore unless you are absolutely certain that you fall within these lines do not plan for Need Based Scholarships. 

OTHER USEFUL TIPS

  • The amounts awarded and requirements vary greatly from school to school. Therefore, it is crucial to understand the specifics of your school.
  • With regards to Need Based Scholarships there is a lot of information that is intertwined with your federal and state financial aid forms. 
  • It is usually not required for someone to fill out their FAFSA or CSS to receive Merit scholarships, but it is always a good idea to fill them out anyways just in case. 
  • There are many costs involved in college. Understand that if you manage to get a scholarship that pays for your tuition, it might not actually cover your room and board costs. Try to always understand what is the number that you have to pay. 
  • These scholarships are sometimes affected by when you submit your application, so the common rule of thumb is to submit them as early as you can. You do not have to be a few months early, but you should never be late. 
  • All scholarships that are given by colleges have requirements to maintain these scholarships. These requirements vary from program to program, but generally all require that you maintain a certain cumulative GPA to continue receiving that scholarship. 
  •  These scholarships are also almost always limited to a regular 4 year undergraduate degree. This means if you do not manage to graduate in 4 years you will have to a pay for everything yourself after those years are up.

Therefore, this number will vary a lot because different schools offer different amounts of money. Today we will discuss the two main types of aid that a colleges usually provide to their students. These types are called Merit Scholarships and Need Based Scholarships. 

","align":"left","text_color":"#000000","typography_typography":"custom","typography_font_family":"Arial","typography_font_size":{"unit":"px","size":18,"sizes":[]},"text_columns":"1","_background_background":"gradient","_background_color":"#FFFFFF","_background_color_b":"#FFFFFF","_background_gradient_position":"top right","_background_image":{"url":"https://www.collegerealtalk.com/wp-content/uploads/2020/06/Scenic-scaled.jpg","id":1304},"_offset_x":{"size":-69,"unit":"px"},"_offset_y":{"size":34,"unit":"px"},"_background_color_stop":{"unit":"%","size":100,"sizes":[]},"_background_color_b_stop":{"unit":"%","size":0,"sizes":[]}},"elements":[],"widgetType":"text-editor"},{"id":"87ae265","elType":"widget","settings":{"title":"NOTE: NOT EVERY SCHOOL GIVES MERIT OR NEED BASED SCHOLARSHIPS","title_color":"#000000","typography_typography":"custom","typography_font_family":"Arial","typography_font_size":{"unit":"px","size":18,"sizes":[]}},"elements":[],"widgetType":"heading"}],"isInner":false}],"isInner":false},{"id":"42727cf","elType":"section","settings":{"background_background":"classic","background_color":"#FFFFFF"},"elements":[{"id":"8b1f3ef","elType":"column","settings":{"_column_size":100,"_inline_size":null},"elements":[{"id":"e914ef5","elType":"widget","settings":{"anchor":"MBS"},"elements":[],"widgetType":"menu-anchor"},{"id":"a3d3a64","elType":"widget","settings":[],"elements":[],"widgetType":"spacer"},{"id":"59e8c41","elType":"widget","settings":{"title":"WHAT ARE MERIT BASED SCHOLARSHIPS?","title_color":"#1378DD","typography_typography":"custom","typography_font_family":"Arial","typography_font_size":{"unit":"px","size":40,"sizes":[]},"_background_background":"classic","_background_color":"#FFFFFF","align":"center"},"elements":[],"widgetType":"heading"},{"id":"089b038","elType":"widget","settings":{"editor":"

Merit Scholarships are usually specified amounts of money given to students as grants meaning that they do not need to be paid back. Think of Merit Scholarships as an award that you have earned. In any given college, only a limited number of students receive Merit Scholarships so if you have received one that is very impressive! Merit Scholarships are usually determined in two different ways. They can either be solely grade based or holistic based. 

Merit Scholarships are usually scholarships that schools give prior to your enrollment. Occasionally depending on your school these scholarships can also be obtained if you perform well during your college years. For example, certain schools offer a scholarship for students who make the Dean's list (an award for reaching a certain GPA in a semester). So if you did not receive a scholarship when you enrolled it is possible to eventually work hard and receive one. However, in the majority of cases merit scholarships are usually determined prior to your enrollment. 

","text_color":"#000000","typography_typography":"custom","typography_font_family":"Arial","typography_font_size":{"unit":"px","size":18,"sizes":[]},"_background_background":"classic","_background_color":"#FFFFFF"},"elements":[],"widgetType":"text-editor"}],"isInner":false}],"isInner":false},{"id":"6db278f","elType":"section","settings":{"background_background":"classic","background_color":"#FFFFFF"},"elements":[{"id":"377be7c","elType":"column","settings":{"_column_size":100,"_inline_size":null},"elements":[{"id":"874b7f9","elType":"widget","settings":{"anchor":"GBMS"},"elements":[],"widgetType":"menu-anchor"},{"id":"044395f","elType":"widget","settings":[],"elements":[],"widgetType":"spacer"},{"id":"33dc1b0","elType":"widget","settings":{"title":"GRADE BASED MERIT SCHOLARSHIPS (GBMS)","align":"center","title_color":"#1378DD","typography_typography":"custom","typography_font_family":"Arial","typography_font_size":{"unit":"px","size":40,"sizes":[]},"_background_background":"classic","_background_color":"#FFFFFF"},"elements":[],"widgetType":"heading"},{"id":"cd5f120","elType":"widget","settings":{"editor":"

Grade based scholarships are usually the easiest to determine your eligibility in receiving them. The required scores that an applicant must hit are usually posted on the college's websites. Sometimes they also require that you are from a certain background, like for example a first generation student, before you qualify for the scholarship. Colleges will specify their requirements and usually they have just number requirements that they require to be hit. Take for example the "Presidential Scholarship" from NJCU (New Jersey City University).

","text_color":"#000000","typography_typography":"custom","typography_font_family":"Arial","typography_font_size":{"unit":"px","size":18,"sizes":[]},"_background_background":"classic","_background_color":"#FFFFFF"},"elements":[],"widgetType":"text-editor"}],"isInner":false}],"isInner":false},{"id":"e4288cb","elType":"section","settings":{"background_background":"classic","background_color":"#FFFFFF"},"elements":[{"id":"6be0972","elType":"column","settings":{"_column_size":100,"_inline_size":null},"elements":[{"id":"102e063","elType":"widget","settings":{"image":{"url":"https://www.collegerealtalk.com/wp-content/uploads/2020/06/Presidential-Scholarship-NJCU.jpg","id":1826}},"elements":[],"widgetType":"image"}],"isInner":false}],"isInner":false},{"id":"6eab974","elType":"section","settings":{"background_background":"classic","background_color":"#FFFFFF"},"elements":[{"id":"f018dbe","elType":"column","settings":{"_column_size":100,"_inline_size":null},"elements":[{"id":"ad51928","elType":"widget","settings":{"editor":"

As you see above, for a full ride at NJCU all an applicant needs to hit is a 3.00 GPA and a 1270 SAT or 26 ACT score. Once you have hit those specified numbers you are basically guaranteed the scholarship if you are admitted to that college. However, sometimes colleges are not as open to telling their applicants what the specific numbers that they need to hit are. So it is important to first understand how your college operates. 

","text_color":"#000000","typography_typography":"custom","typography_font_family":"Arial","typography_font_size":{"unit":"px","size":18,"sizes":[]},"_background_background":"classic","_background_color":"#FFFFFF"},"elements":[],"widgetType":"text-editor"}],"isInner":false}],"isInner":false},{"id":"17845c2","elType":"section","settings":{"background_background":"classic","background_color":"#FFFFFF"},"elements":[{"id":"08ae8ff","elType":"column","settings":{"_column_size":100,"_inline_size":null},"elements":[{"id":"e31ac31","elType":"widget","settings":{"anchor":"HBMS"},"elements":[],"widgetType":"menu-anchor"},{"id":"d181c43","elType":"widget","settings":[],"elements":[],"widgetType":"spacer"},{"id":"20f673f","elType":"widget","settings":{"title":"HOLISTIC BASED MERIT SCHOLARSHIPS (HBMS)","align":"center","title_color":"#1378DD","typography_typography":"custom","typography_font_family":"Arial","typography_font_size":{"unit":"px","size":40,"sizes":[]},"_background_background":"classic","_background_color":"#FFFFFF"},"elements":[],"widgetType":"heading"},{"id":"1d17f2f","elType":"widget","settings":{"editor":"

Holistic Based Merit Scholarships usually take into account other factors other than purely grades. It is important to understand that grades still matter, but they will not be the sole determiner in whether someone receives a scholarship or not. These similar to Grade Based Merit Scholarships are also usually determined prior to your enrollment. These scholarships are also usually listed on a college's website, but they usually give vague descriptions of what they want in an applicant. Unlike the Grade based scholarships sometimes these Holistic Scholarships require an additional application, but this is not always the case. There are also cases we have seen where these HBMS come in form of scholar programs. They require students to take extra classes and commit to certain projects in order to maintain the status of their scholarship. They are also frequently referred to as Honors Programs, but of course this differs from school to school. Sometimes colleges have a dedicated Honors program that has a required Grade cut-off, while some schools admit Honor Students through a holistic review. The Martin Luther King, Jr. Scholars Program at New York University is one example of such programs. 

","text_color":"#000000","typography_typography":"custom","typography_font_family":"Arial","typography_font_size":{"unit":"px","size":18,"sizes":[]},"_background_background":"classic","_background_color":"#FFFFFF"},"elements":[],"widgetType":"text-editor"}],"isInner":false}],"isInner":false},{"id":"2769cc4","elType":"section","settings":{"background_background":"classic","background_color":"#FFFFFF"},"elements":[{"id":"56027e2","elType":"column","settings":{"_column_size":100,"_inline_size":null},"elements":[{"id":"1d40b0d","elType":"widget","settings":{"image":{"url":"https://www.collegerealtalk.com/wp-content/uploads/2020/06/MLK-Scholarship.jpg","id":1835},"_border_border":"solid","_border_color":"#000000","_border_radius":{"unit":"px","top":"0","right":"0","bottom":"0","left":"0","isLinked":true}},"elements":[],"widgetType":"image"}],"isInner":false}],"isInner":false},{"id":"06b7ef2","elType":"section","settings":{"background_background":"classic","background_color":"#FFFFFF"},"elements":[{"id":"a5da7b1","elType":"column","settings":{"_column_size":100,"_inline_size":null},"elements":[{"id":"b7a1757","elType":"widget","settings":{"editor":"

As you see above, this scholarship is treated more like a program where you are required to take certain classes and participate in certain events. However, when we view it from our broke college student perspectives this is an awesome program, but an even more awesome full ride for your 4 years New York University. 

","text_color":"#000000","typography_typography":"custom","typography_font_family":"Arial","typography_font_size":{"unit":"px","size":18,"sizes":[]},"_background_background":"classic","_background_color":"#FFFFFF"},"elements":[],"widgetType":"text-editor"}],"isInner":false}],"isInner":false},{"id":"320eac5","elType":"section","settings":{"background_background":"classic","background_color":"#FFFFFF"},"elements":[{"id":"18a4ed3","elType":"column","settings":{"_column_size":100,"_inline_size":null},"elements":[{"id":"2756f72","elType":"widget","settings":{"title":"NOTE: The examples we shown were just one sample of each type of scholarship. Just because in our example the MLK scholarship offered more money does not mean that HBMS offer more than GBMS. These numbers and requirements are specific to these schools only. ","title_color":"#000000","typography_typography":"custom","typography_font_family":"Arial","typography_font_size":{"unit":"px","size":18,"sizes":[]}},"elements":[],"widgetType":"heading"}],"isInner":false}],"isInner":false},{"id":"df89449","elType":"section","settings":{"background_background":"classic","background_color":"#FFFFFF"},"elements":[{"id":"4bc1149","elType":"column","settings":{"_column_size":100,"_inline_size":null},"elements":[{"id":"2bc26e9","elType":"widget","settings":{"anchor":"NBS"},"elements":[],"widgetType":"menu-anchor"},{"id":"bef532d","elType":"widget","settings":[],"elements":[],"widgetType":"spacer"},{"id":"08c756d","elType":"widget","settings":{"title":"WHAT ARE NEED BASED SCHOLARSHIPS?","align":"center","title_color":"#1378DD","typography_typography":"custom","typography_font_family":"Arial","typography_font_size":{"unit":"px","size":40,"sizes":[]},"_background_background":"classic","_background_color":"#FFFFFF"},"elements":[],"widgetType":"heading"},{"id":"91a93b1","elType":"widget","settings":{"editor":"

Need Based Scholarships are scholarships that schools give to certain students based on the information provided to the schools from when the students fill out the FAFSA or CSS. Basically, when you fill out one of these financial aid forms that you provide is processed and given to the schools that you are applying for. The schools then shift through the processed forms and determine which students, whom they have admitted, need additional financial aid the most. It is also common to see states or other organizations give these scholarships to students, but these scholarships are obviously not given to you from your school. Universities that offer extensive Need Based Scholarships usually outline very clearly their requirements in receiving these scholarships. It is also very common for an applicant to provide further proof to finalize these types of scholarships. These scholarships are less in one's control and really just up to a student's personal life situation and income. The income brackets that usually receive these scholarships are extremely close to poverty lines, and therefore unless you are absolutely certain that you fall within these lines do not plan for Need Based Scholarships. 

","text_color":"#000000","typography_typography":"custom","typography_font_family":"Arial","typography_font_size":{"unit":"px","size":19,"sizes":[]},"_background_background":"classic","_background_color":"#FFFFFF"},"elements":[],"widgetType":"text-editor"}],"isInner":false}],"isInner":false},{"id":"fa80524","elType":"section","settings":{"background_background":"classic","background_color":"#FFFFFF"},"elements":[{"id":"9cabcf1","elType":"column","settings":{"_column_size":100,"_inline_size":null},"elements":[{"id":"dc6a782","elType":"widget","settings":{"anchor":"SIT"},"elements":[],"widgetType":"menu-anchor"},{"id":"fa2bc52","elType":"widget","settings":[],"elements":[],"widgetType":"spacer"},{"id":"6ebaf29","elType":"widget","settings":{"title":"OTHER USEFUL TIPS","align":"center","title_color":"#000000","typography_typography":"custom","typography_font_family":"Arial","typography_font_size":{"unit":"px","size":40,"sizes":[]},"typography_font_weight":"700"},"elements":[],"widgetType":"heading"}],"isInner":false}],"isInner":false},{"id":"58c4f2d","elType":"section","settings":{"structure":"20","background_background":"classic","background_color":"#FFFFFF"},"elements":[{"id":"5440760","elType":"column","settings":{"_column_size":50,"_inline_size":null},"elements":[{"id":"8a5542c","elType":"widget","settings":{"editor":"
  • The amounts awarded and requirements vary greatly from school to school. Therefore, it is crucial to understand the specifics of your school.
  • With regards to Need Based Scholarships there is a lot of information that is intertwined with your federal and state financial aid forms. 
  • It is usually not required for someone to fill out their FAFSA or CSS to receive Merit scholarships, but it is always a good idea to fill them out anyways just in case. 
  • There are many costs involved in college. Understand that if you manage to get a scholarship that pays for your tuition, it might not actually cover your room and board costs. Try to always understand what is the number that you have to pay. 
","align":"left","text_color":"#000000","typography_typography":"custom","typography_font_size":{"unit":"px","size":18,"sizes":[]},"text_columns":"1","_background_background":"classic","_background_color":"#FFFFFF"},"elements":[],"widgetType":"text-editor"}],"isInner":false},{"id":"3366c47","elType":"column","settings":{"_column_size":50,"_inline_size":null},"elements":[{"id":"f1e7bfb","elType":"widget","settings":{"editor":"
  • These scholarships are sometimes affected by when you submit your application, so the common rule of thumb is to submit them as early as you can. You do not have to be a few months early, but you should never be late. 
  • All scholarships that are given by colleges have requirements to maintain these scholarships. These requirements vary from program to program, but generally all require that you maintain a certain cumulative GPA to continue receiving that scholarship. 
  •  These scholarships are also almost always limited to a regular 4 year undergraduate degree. This means if you do not manage to graduate in 4 years you will have to a pay for everything yourself after those years are up. 
","align":"left","text_color":"#000000","typography_typography":"custom","typography_font_size":{"unit":"px","size":18,"sizes":[]},"text_columns":"1","_background_background":"classic","_background_color":"#FFFFFF"},"elements":[],"widgetType":"text-editor"}],"isInner":false}],"isInner":false}]

item.title: State Aid
item.dc:creator: qb4htu
item.content:encoded:
State aid "HESAA"

What is state aid?

What is state aid? Much like the FAFSA, state aid is given out based on your financial standing and is not based on your academic performance in college or high school. State aid, or in this case HESAA for New Jersey, does not need to be repaid just like grants received from the FAFSA and can be given out on a year to year basis. This is not to be confused with Stafford loans that you’ll see on your awards page; those must be repaid and are not free. These loans are good, however, as they require you to repay lest than other non-government loans would from interest. Unlike FAFSA, state aid is only limited to in-state colleges; for example, if you live in New Jersey and plan on going to NYU in New York, you will not receive state aid from NJ or NY. Grants given out through state aid varies in amount based on a combination of your financial status and cost of attendance for the college itself. For instance, you’ll receive more assistance for a college that charges $20k for tuition instead of one that charges $10k.

Before starting HESAA, make sure to finish your FAFSA application! Check out our step by tutorial by clicking here.

How to apply for HESAA Step by Step

Step 1: Head over to HESAA's Website

Step 2: Creating an account

When creating an account, the information typed in needs to be entered exactly as it is entered in your FAFSA (This includes apostrophes or any other symbols).

Step 3: Choosing your Schools

Click on "View and Update Your School" then click on "Add a School" from the drop-down box search for the school or schools you wish to add. You can add multiple schools, including those you applied for, but have not yet received a decision from. However, the schools must match the same ones you chose on the FAFSA application, or you will not receive aid.

NOTE: THE SCHOOLS CHOSEN MUST MATCH THE ONES ON YOUR FASFA APPLICATION THAT ARE IN NEW JERSEY

Step 4: Checking if HESAA has received your FAFSA application

If this is your first time doing HESAA, it will say not received. It takes about 2-3 business days for HESAA to receive applications. This is the same if you're renewing HESAA.

Step 5: Checking your grants

You'll see the amount of aid granted split into the fall and spring semester, along with the total amount of state aid given.

Step 6: Accept the grants through your college

Finally, you want to accept the grants through your college portal. Most colleges have financial aid and awards under their student account. From there, you'll be able to accept FAFSA and any state aid. Colleges typically allow you to accept grants when the first bill is posted.

That's it, you're all set!

Check out our other guides for CSS and School Aid for more help funding your college life, or visit our forums if you have any questions! CSS School Aid Forums

item.title: CSS
item.dc:creator: qb4htu
item.content:encoded:
CSS Profile

There is another separate application offered by college board called the CSS profile. The CSS is often used by schools in conjunction with the FAFSA to determine how much aid you are eligible for.Keep in mind that, unlike the FAFSA, the CSS profile is not free. Fee waivers are available for the CSS profiles however. You can find more info on the CSS here. https://cssprofile.collegeboard.org/ The CSS asks for more information than the FAFSA (typically medical expenses and housing information). The CSS is often used to determine how much institutional aid you qualify for, in other words how much money the school itself can give you. We provide an overview of what the CSS profile form may look like below. *NOTE* Questions may differ depending on answers given to certain questions. This is just some basic confirmation information. You have probably filled out this information a million times already.  The only question that might confuse you is the "CBFinAid ID."
  • In order to find this ID sign into your CSS account on CollegeBoard
  • Then Click Dashboard at the top right corner and your ID will be there
For the student citizenship just answer honestly and take a look at your most used passport if you are having trouble.  These questions are straightforward. Make sure to answer these questions as truthfully and completely as you can as incorrect answers might affect your aid amount. This information is asking you where do you live now that is your primary home. If you are having trouble here the idea is to put down the address that you plan on living at the longest that is not your college dorm.  This question is just to confirm your contact information. Try your best to be as accurate and complete as possible as filling out of this incorrectly could affect the amount of aid you will receive.  In this question list all of your parents and their relationships towards you as the student. This question is straightforward. However, if you cannot answer this question by asking your parents, then looking at their taxes could also help to answer this question.  This question is straightforward. Just remember that your answers should be as recent as possible, and once again pay attention to the specific dates that they ask about.  This part is straightforward just answer honestly and pay attention to the dates that they are asking for.  So this part is very important because what schools you put down here will determine what schools will receive your CSS. If you are currently applying for colleges just put down all of the schools that have indicated that they either require or recommend a CSS profile. Remember that there is a flat fee of $25 to fill out and to send out the CSS to one school. If you decide to send the CSS to additional schools each additional school will cost you $16 more.  For example, if you were to send a CSS profile to two different colleges then you would be paying: 25 + 16 = $41 It is possible to get fee waivers for the CSS profile. Generally, if your family makes less than $40,000 a year then you probably would qualify for a waiver.  This is more information that you will provide so that the CSS can more accurately determine your aid eligibility. Obviously, if you will be dorming during college your tuition will be significantly higher than if you were able to reasonably commute to college. Be sure to indicate that you will be dorming if you plan to because that will be a factor in determining if you get aid or not! These questions will be for any guardian that you put down. To answer these questions you will need to ask your guardian(s) about it. If they do not remember the highest level of education completed you can just put your most accurate guess.  The quickest way to answer these employment questions is to ask your parent or guardian, however, if you cannot do that you can find their employment status on their taxes.  The general rule for this question is that if your parents or guardian do not know what a certain plan is they probably do not have that plan. Ask your guardian to see if they do. However, if you have parents or family who barely speak any English (like some of ours) they might not be too aware of the specific one that they have. Your parents will probably know if they have a retirement plan, but sometimes they might not know which specific type it is. In this case, it is a good idea to contact your guardian's bank, Human Resources department, or money managing app/accountant and ask them directly.  These are questions that will either require you to ask your guardian(s) or to look at their tax forms directly. If they are unable or unsure about some of the answers to these questions, try asking bank or HR staff as suggested before.  Tax filing assistance apps and websites can help you and a guardian find out what sections of your tax forms include certain information that you need. Try using them if you feel stuck! It is important here to pay attention to the dates that are given in the question. For example, in this specific past CSS profile it asked you to put down the amounts received in 2018, but do not get confused by the 2020-21 date.  This question is about child support that is either received or given by your parents. Once again pay close attention to the dates that are provided and answer the questions accordingly.  This is a straightforward question about your parents' home address. You can provide the home address of each parent or guardian individually. This is a straightforward housing question no need to overthink things. Choose the option that best fits your family’s housing situation.  If you live with family but are not paying rent or mortgage, choose "live with others". "Own home" will ask you to detail monthly payments, as well as "rent home"; the amount of money you need to spend for your housing will affect how much money the CSS thinks you need to be able to attend college. When you're on the CSS page they clearly list out examples of what they consider assets and investments. These include real estate, stocks, and stuff like that.  This question will affect your aid, but you should definitely not lie here; you don't want big daddy government to come knocking on your door for tax and payment fraud! This question is more direct and is not asking for an average so just be sure to use exact amounts to rid yourself of all liabilities.  If your guardian(s) have to pay any of these, check it off. Alimonies are reparations paid after a divorce from one former partner to another.  Lying about any of these reeeaally isn't worth the trouble it's gonna cause. Dependents are people, other than the your guardian(s) and yourself, who receive more than half of their support from your guardian(s). Dependents might include other relatives or non-blood related family. Be sure to include everyone who is a dependent. The more the merrier. These questions are only applicable if you filled out taxes for the year that they're asking for. Hopefully, you yourself knew whether or not you had filled out taxes or not. If you did them yourself, good job- this question should be a breeze!  If not then you probably had help, and should ask your guardian(s) or other resource for help finding the information. These questions mirror that of your parent's expected income and benefits, and hopefully will be easier to fill out because they are questions regarding yourself. Putting down zeroes is a perfectly valid answer, don't worry. These questions are pretty straightforward just remember to answer truthfully. Only write down money you know you will or have received for sure, and those that are officially recorded significant sums. Don't write down the twenty bucks you got from Uncle Ben to go eat something good at college. It is not worth lying! Same as before. The investments are the same kinds of things as described under the parent section.  These questions are simple yes or no questions. If you're able to say yes to any of these, kudos to you! I wish I could. Remember that even if you family owns a farm (or anything else), they asset does not count as the student's unless it is under your name.  This section is for letting the CSS know about anything that you were unable to convey in your application. If you select any of these options you will be prompted to elaborate in writing. This is the last section before you submit so fill this out if you feel like you are missing something important that could help your case.  Remember the goal of the CSS is to prove to your school that you need more financial aid. If you really believe that you need more aid please submit a full application, and anything that you cannot express in the other questions please elaborate them here!
