    This part is straightforward just answer honestly and pay attention to the dates that they are asking for.\u00a0<\/p>","text_color":"#000000","typography_typography":"custom","typography_font_family":"Arial","typography_font_size":{"unit":"px","size":15,"sizes":[]}},"elements":[],"widgetType":"text-editor"}],"isInner":false}],"isInner":false},{"id":"34b3077","elType":"section","settings":[],"elements":[{"id":"6114d61","elType":"column","settings":{"_column_size":100,"_inline_size":null},"elements":[{"id":"ce1007a","elType":"widget","settings":{"anchor":"9"},"elements":[],"widgetType":"menu-anchor"},{"id":"ee23d74","elType":"widget","settings":[],"elements":[],"widgetType":"spacer"},{"id":"9419a98","elType":"widget","settings":{"image":{"url":"https:\/\/www.collegerealtalk.com\/wp-content\/uploads\/2020\/07\/9-2.jpg","id":2404},"image_size":"medium_large","caption_source":"custom"},"elements":[],"widgetType":"image"},{"id":"2ab2fbb","elType":"widget","settings":{"editor":"

    So this part is very important<\/b> because what schools you put down here will determine what schools will receive your CSS. If you are currently applying for colleges just put down all of the schools that have indicated that they either require or recommend a CSS profile. Remember that there is a flat fee of\u00a0$25<\/b> to fill out and to send out the CSS to one school. If you decide to send the CSS to additional schools each additional school will cost you $16<\/b> more.\u00a0<\/p>

    For example, if you were to send a CSS profile to two different colleges then you would be paying:\u00a025 + 16 = $41<\/p>

    It is possible to get fee waivers<\/b> for the CSS profile. Generally, if your family makes less than $40,000 a year then you probably would qualify for a waiver.\u00a0<\/p>","text_color":"#000000","typography_typography":"custom","typography_font_family":"Arial","typography_font_size":{"unit":"px","size":15,"sizes":[]}},"elements":[],"widgetType":"text-editor"}],"isInner":false}],"isInner":false},{"id":"d20336f","elType":"section","settings":[],"elements":[{"id":"8e9e65b","elType":"column","settings":{"_column_size":100,"_inline_size":null},"elements":[{"id":"bc956af","elType":"widget","settings":{"anchor":"10"},"elements":[],"widgetType":"menu-anchor"},{"id":"5a21588","elType":"widget","settings":[],"elements":[],"widgetType":"spacer"},{"id":"18b7da8","elType":"widget","settings":{"image":{"url":"https:\/\/www.collegerealtalk.com\/wp-content\/uploads\/2020\/07\/10-2.jpg","id":2405},"image_size":"medium_large","caption_source":"custom"},"elements":[],"widgetType":"image"},{"id":"8ef1bc3","elType":"widget","settings":{"editor":"

    This is more information that you will provide so that the CSS can more accurately determine your aid eligibility. Obviously, if you will be dorming during college your tuition will be significantly higher than if you were able to reasonably commute to college. Be sure to indicate that you will be dorming if you plan to because that will be a factor in determining if you get aid or not!<\/p>","text_color":"#000000","typography_typography":"custom","typography_font_family":"Arial","typography_font_size":{"unit":"px","size":15,"sizes":[]}},"elements":[],"widgetType":"text-editor"}],"isInner":false}],"isInner":false},{"id":"0c7b41f","elType":"section","settings":[],"elements":[{"id":"73fe540","elType":"column","settings":{"_column_size":100,"_inline_size":null},"elements":[{"id":"db26255","elType":"widget","settings":{"anchor":"11"},"elements":[],"widgetType":"menu-anchor"},{"id":"1274a0c","elType":"widget","settings":[],"elements":[],"widgetType":"spacer"},{"id":"171f40d","elType":"widget","settings":{"image":{"url":"https:\/\/www.collegerealtalk.com\/wp-content\/uploads\/2020\/07\/11-2.jpg","id":2407},"image_size":"medium_large","caption_source":"custom"},"elements":[],"widgetType":"image"},{"id":"27befa8","elType":"widget","settings":{"editor":"

    These questions will be for any guardian that you put down. To answer these questions you will need to ask your guardian(s) about it. If they do not remember the highest level of education completed you can just put your most accurate guess.\u00a0<\/p>

    The quickest way to answer these employment questions is to ask your parent or guardian, however, if you cannot do that you can find their employment status on their taxes.\u00a0<\/p>","text_color":"#000000","typography_typography":"custom","typography_font_family":"Arial","typography_font_size":{"unit":"px","size":15,"sizes":[]}},"elements":[],"widgetType":"text-editor"}],"isInner":false}],"isInner":false},{"id":"42ba7c8","elType":"section","settings":[],"elements":[{"id":"17178ae","elType":"column","settings":{"_column_size":100,"_inline_size":null},"elements":[{"id":"2a723c0","elType":"widget","settings":{"editor":"","text_color":"#000000","typography_typography":"custom","typography_font_family":"Arial","typography_font_size":{"unit":"px","size":15,"sizes":[]}},"elements":[],"widgetType":"text-editor"},{"id":"4167f04","elType":"widget","settings":{"anchor":"12"},"elements":[],"widgetType":"menu-anchor"},{"id":"0cb56b8","elType":"widget","settings":[],"elements":[],"widgetType":"spacer"},{"id":"947c838","elType":"widget","settings":{"image":{"url":"https:\/\/www.collegerealtalk.com\/wp-content\/uploads\/2020\/07\/11.5.jpg","id":2406},"image_size":"medium_large","caption_source":"custom"},"elements":[],"widgetType":"image"},{"id":"d11cb6a","elType":"widget","settings":{"editor":"

    The general rule for this question is that if your parents or guardian do not know what a certain plan is they probably do not have that plan. Ask your guardian to see if they do. However, if you have parents or family who barely speak any English (like some of ours) they might not be too aware of the specific one that they have. Your parents will probably know if they have a retirement plan, but sometimes they might not know which specific type it is. In this case, it is a good idea to contact your guardian's bank, Human Resources department, or money managing app\/accountant
    and ask them directly.\u00a0<\/p>","text_color":"#000000","typography_typography":"custom","typography_font_family":"Arial","typography_font_size":{"unit":"px","size":15,"sizes":[]}},"elements":[],"widgetType":"text-editor"}],"isInner":false}],"isInner":false},{"id":"946a66d","elType":"section","settings":[],"elements":[{"id":"2088193","elType":"column","settings":{"_column_size":100,"_inline_size":null},"elements":[{"id":"f570d0d","elType":"widget","settings":{"anchor":"13"},"elements":[],"widgetType":"menu-anchor"},{"id":"bf1a535","elType":"widget","settings":[],"elements":[],"widgetType":"spacer"},{"id":"2f398d3","elType":"widget","settings":{"image":{"url":"https:\/\/www.collegerealtalk.com\/wp-content\/uploads\/2020\/07\/12-2.jpg","id":2408},"image_size":"medium_large","caption_source":"custom"},"elements":[],"widgetType":"image"},{"id":"5ec394a","elType":"widget","settings":{"editor":"

    These are questions that will either require you to ask your guardian(s) or to look at their tax forms directly. If they are unable or unsure about some of the answers to these questions, try asking bank or HR staff as suggested before.\u00a0<\/p>

    Tax filing assistance apps and websites can help you and a guardian find out what sections of your tax forms include certain information that you need. Try using them if you feel stuck!<\/p>","text_color":"#000000","typography_typography":"custom","typography_font_family":"Arial","typography_font_size":{"unit":"px","size":15,"sizes":[]}},"elements":[],"widgetType":"text-editor"}],"isInner":false}],"isInner":false},{"id":"e52d005","elType":"section","settings":[],"elements":[{"id":"83f595e","elType":"column","settings":{"_column_size":100,"_inline_size":null},"elements":[{"id":"37aa0d0","elType":"widget","settings":{"anchor":"14"},"elements":[],"widgetType":"menu-anchor"},{"id":"280cd04","elType":"widget","settings":[],"elements":[],"widgetType":"spacer"},{"id":"c80c355","elType":"widget","settings":{"image":{"url":"https:\/\/www.collegerealtalk.com\/wp-content\/uploads\/2020\/07\/13-2.jpg","id":2409},"image_size":"medium_large","caption_source":"custom"},"elements":[],"widgetType":"image"},{"id":"c4e4031","elType":"widget","settings":{"editor":"

    It is important here to pay attention to the dates that are given in the question. For example, in this specific past CSS profile it asked you to put down the amounts received in 2018, but do not get confused by the 2020-21 date.\u00a0<\/p>","text_color":"#000000","typography_typography":"custom","typography_font_family":"Arial","typography_font_size":{"unit":"px","size":15,"sizes":[]}},"elements":[],"widgetType":"text-editor"}],"isInner":false}],"isInner":false},{"id":"9b5998a","elType":"section","settings":[],"elements":[{"id":"b0ca0e4","elType":"column","settings":{"_column_size":100,"_inline_size":null},"elements":[{"id":"d2cb2c2","elType":"widget","settings":{"anchor":"15"},"elements":[],"widgetType":"menu-anchor"},{"id":"3ce2a92","elType":"widget","settings":[],"elements":[],"widgetType":"spacer"},{"id":"a922e30","elType":"widget","settings":{"image":{"url":"https:\/\/www.collegerealtalk.com\/wp-content\/uploads\/2020\/07\/14-2.jpg","id":2410},"image_size":"medium_large","caption_source":"custom","text_color":"#000000"},"elements":[],"widgetType":"image"},{"id":"d99e418","elType":"widget","settings":{"editor":"

    This question is about child support that is either received or given by your parents. Once again pay close attention to the dates that are provided and answer the questions accordingly.\u00a0<\/p>","text_color":"#000000","typography_typography":"custom","typography_font_family":"Arial","typography_font_size":{"unit":"px","size":15,"sizes":[]}},"elements":[],"widgetType":"text-editor"}],"isInner":false}],"isInner":false},{"id":"bb4f618","elType":"section","settings":[],"elements":[{"id":"0744163","elType":"column","settings":{"_column_size":100,"_inline_size":null},"elements":[{"id":"037779c","elType":"widget","settings":{"anchor":"16"},"elements":[],"widgetType":"menu-anchor"},{"id":"36736a0","elType":"widget","settings":[],"elements":[],"widgetType":"spacer"},{"id":"529623d","elType":"widget","settings":{"image":{"url":"https:\/\/www.collegerealtalk.com\/wp-content\/uploads\/2020\/07\/15-2.jpg","id":2411},"image_size":"medium_large","caption_source":"custom"},"elements":[],"widgetType":"image"},{"id":"0c2f44b","elType":"widget","settings":{"editor":"

    This is a straightforward question about your parents' home address. You can provide the home address of each parent or guardian individually.<\/p>","text_color":"#000000","typography_typography":"custom","typography_font_family":"Arial","typography_font_size":{"unit":"px","size":15,"sizes":[]}},"elements":[],"widgetType":"text-editor"}],"isInner":false}],"isInner":false},{"id":"bbacdee","elType":"section","settings":[],"elements":[{"id":"e31f493","elType":"column","settings":{"_column_size":100,"_inline_size":null},"elements":[{"id":"f6ee244","elType":"widget","settings":{"anchor":"17"},"elements":[],"widgetType":"menu-anchor"},{"id":"9a4d3f3","elType":"widget","settings":[],"elements":[],"widgetType":"spacer"},{"id":"d6162b1","elType":"widget","settings":{"image":{"url":"https:\/\/www.collegerealtalk.com\/wp-content\/uploads\/2020\/07\/16-1.jpg","id":2412},"image_size":"medium_large","caption_source":"custom"},"elements":[],"widgetType":"image"},{"id":"b43ddd0","elType":"widget","settings":{"editor":"

    This is a straightforward housing question no need to overthink things. Choose the option that best fits your family\u2019s housing situation.\u00a0<\/p>

    If you live with family but are not paying rent or mortgage, choose \"live with others\". \"Own home\" will ask you to detail monthly payments, as well as \"rent home\"; the amount of money you need to spend for your housing will affect how much money the CSS thinks you need to be able to attend college.<\/p>","text_color":"#000000","typography_typography":"custom","typography_font_family":"Arial","typography_font_size":{"unit":"px","size":15,"sizes":[]}},"elements":[],"widgetType":"text-editor"}],"isInner":false}],"isInner":false},{"id":"d503ae4","elType":"section","settings":[],"elements":[{"id":"83e1922","elType":"column","settings":{"_column_size":100,"_inline_size":null},"elements":[{"id":"f52acc0","elType":"widget","settings":{"anchor":"18"},"elements":[],"widgetType":"menu-anchor"},{"id":"addfbeb","elType":"widget","settings":[],"elements":[],"widgetType":"spacer"},{"id":"ed91d57","elType":"widget","settings":{"image":{"url":"https:\/\/www.collegerealtalk.com\/wp-content\/uploads\/2020\/07\/17-1.jpg","id":2413},"image_size":"medium_large","caption_source":"custom"},"elements":[],"widgetType":"image"},{"id":"713fa83","elType":"widget","settings":{"editor":"

    When you're on the CSS page they clearly list out examples of what they consider assets and investments. These include real estate, stocks, and stuff like that.\u00a0<\/p>

    This question will affect your aid, but you should definitely not lie here; you don't want big daddy government to come knocking on your door for tax and payment fraud!<\/p>","text_color":"#000000","typography_typography":"custom","typography_font_family":"Arial","typography_font_size":{"unit":"px","size":15,"sizes":[]}},"elements":[],"widgetType":"text-editor"}],"isInner":false}],"isInner":false},{"id":"febc0ec","elType":"section","settings":[],"elements":[{"id":"111eb60","elType":"column","settings":{"_column_size":100,"_inline_size":null},"elements":[{"id":"1348662","elType":"widget","settings":{"anchor":"19"},"elements":[],"widgetType":"menu-anchor"},{"id":"abefbff","elType":"widget","settings":[],"elements":[],"widgetType":"spacer"},{"id":"0b69baf","elType":"widget","settings":{"image":{"url":"https:\/\/www.collegerealtalk.com\/wp-content\/uploads\/2020\/07\/18-1.jpg","id":2414},"image_size":"medium_large","caption_source":"custom"},"elements":[],"widgetType":"image"},{"id":"f4f0d38","elType":"widget","settings":{"editor":"

    This question is more direct and is not asking for an average so just be sure to use exact amounts to rid yourself of all liabilities.\u00a0<\/p>","text_color":"#000000","typography_typography":"custom","typography_font_family":"Arial","typography_font_size":{"unit":"px","size":15,"sizes":[]}},"elements":[],"widgetType":"text-editor"}],"isInner":false}],"isInner":false},{"id":"46f33ac","elType":"section","settings":[],"elements":[{"id":"e13632e","elType":"column","settings":{"_column_size":100,"_inline_size":null},"elements":[{"id":"d709b46","elType":"widget","settings":{"anchor":"20"},"elements":[],"widgetType":"menu-anchor"},{"id":"54460a0","elType":"widget","settings":[],"elements":[],"widgetType":"spacer"},{"id":"7d0d99b","elType":"widget","settings":{"image":{"url":"https:\/\/www.collegerealtalk.com\/wp-content\/uploads\/2020\/07\/19-1.jpg","id":2415},"image_size":"medium_large","caption_source":"custom"},"elements":[],"widgetType":"image"},{"id":"124d411","elType":"widget","settings":{"editor":"

    If your guardian(s) have to pay any of these, check it off. Alimonies are reparations paid after a divorce from one former partner to another.\u00a0<\/p>

    Lying about any of these reeeaally isn't worth the trouble it's gonna cause.<\/p>","text_color":"#000000","typography_typography":"custom","typography_font_family":"Arial","typography_font_size":{"unit":"px","size":15,"sizes":[]}},"elements":[],"widgetType":"text-editor"}],"isInner":false}],"isInner":false},{"id":"4dbdf42","elType":"section","settings":[],"elements":[{"id":"4485e08","elType":"column","settings":{"_column_size":100,"_inline_size":null},"elements":[{"id":"10cf71a","elType":"widget","settings":{"anchor":"21"},"elements":[],"widgetType":"menu-anchor"},{"id":"382fa1a","elType":"widget","settings":[],"elements":[],"widgetType":"spacer"},{"id":"3726ea7","elType":"widget","settings":{"image":{"url":"https:\/\/www.collegerealtalk.com\/wp-content\/uploads\/2020\/07\/20-1.jpg","id":2416},"image_size":"medium_large","caption_source":"custom"},"elements":[],"widgetType":"image"},{"id":"3fd0a89","elType":"widget","settings":{"editor":"

    Dependents are people, other than the your guardian(s) and yourself, who receive more than half of their support from your guardian(s). Dependents might include other relatives or non-blood related family. Be sure to include everyone who is a dependent. The more the merrier.<\/p>","text_color":"#000000","typography_typography":"custom","typography_font_family":"Arial","typography_font_size":{"unit":"px","size":15,"sizes":[]}},"elements":[],"widgetType":"text-editor"}],"isInner":false}],"isInner":false},{"id":"b0b9eb6","elType":"section","settings":[],"elements":[{"id":"2012b55","elType":"column","settings":{"_column_size":100,"_inline_size":null},"elements":[{"id":"1a1fafb","elType":"widget","settings":{"anchor":"22"},"elements":[],"widgetType":"menu-anchor"},{"id":"6d24e68","elType":"widget","settings":[],"elements":[],"widgetType":"spacer"},{"id":"9b11c21","elType":"widget","settings":{"image":{"url":"https:\/\/www.collegerealtalk.com\/wp-content\/uploads\/2020\/07\/21-1.jpg","id":2417},"image_size":"medium_large","caption_source":"custom"},"elements":[],"widgetType":"image"},{"id":"e2636c7","elType":"widget","settings":{"editor":"

    These questions are only applicable if you filled out taxes for the year that they're asking for. Hopefully, you yourself knew whether or not you had filled out taxes or not. If you did them yourself, good job- this question should be a breeze!\u00a0<\/p>

    If not then you probably had help, and should ask your guardian(s) or other resource for help finding the information.<\/p>","text_color":"#000000","typography_typography":"custom","typography_font_family":"Arial","typography_font_size":{"unit":"px","size":15,"sizes":[]}},"elements":[],"widgetType":"text-editor"}],"isInner":false}],"isInner":false},{"id":"2a8de60","elType":"section","settings":[],"elements":[{"id":"de80dee","elType":"column","settings":{"_column_size":100,"_inline_size":null},"elements":[{"id":"f39979f","elType":"widget","settings":{"anchor":"23"},"elements":[],"widgetType":"menu-anchor"},{"id":"8012a37","elType":"widget","settings":[],"elements":[],"widgetType":"spacer"},{"id":"4ced4d7","elType":"widget","settings":{"image":{"url":"https:\/\/www.collegerealtalk.com\/wp-content\/uploads\/2020\/07\/22-1.jpg","id":2418},"image_size":"medium_large","caption_source":"custom"},"elements":[],"widgetType":"image"},{"id":"531fad8","elType":"widget","settings":{"editor":"

    These questions mirror that of your parent's expected income and benefits, and hopefully will be easier to fill out because they are questions regarding yourself. Putting down zeroes is a perfectly valid answer, don't worry.<\/p>","text_color":"#000000","typography_typography":"custom","typography_font_family":"Arial","typography_font_size":{"unit":"px","size":15,"sizes":[]}},"elements":[],"widgetType":"text-editor"}],"isInner":false}],"isInner":false},{"id":"4574984","elType":"section","settings":[],"elements":[{"id":"34ecfbd","elType":"column","settings":{"_column_size":100,"_inline_size":null},"elements":[{"id":"a992fa6","elType":"widget","settings":{"editor":"","text_color":"#000000","typography_typography":"custom","typography_font_family":"Arial","typography_font_size":{"unit":"px","size":15,"sizes":[]}},"elements":[],"widgetType":"text-editor"},{"id":"73c94b3","elType":"widget","settings":{"anchor":"24"},"elements":[],"widgetType":"menu-anchor"},{"id":"0deb30a","elType":"widget","settings":[],"elements":[],"widgetType":"spacer"},{"id":"e0787b2","elType":"widget","settings":{"image":{"url":"https:\/\/www.collegerealtalk.com\/wp-content\/uploads\/2020\/07\/23-1.jpg","id":2419},"image_size":"medium_large","caption_source":"custom"},"elements":[],"widgetType":"image"},{"id":"afd47cf","elType":"widget","settings":{"editor":"

    These questions are pretty straightforward just remember to answer truthfully. Only write down money you know you will or have received for sure, and those that are officially recorded significant sums. Don't write down the twenty bucks you got from Uncle Ben to go eat something good at college.<\/p>

    It is not worth lying!<\/p>","text_color":"#000000","typography_typography":"custom","typography_font_family":"Arial","typography_font_size":{"unit":"px","size":15,"sizes":[]}},"elements":[],"widgetType":"text-editor"}],"isInner":false}],"isInner":false},{"id":"9aa7661","elType":"section","settings":[],"elements":[{"id":"4a1cf7c","elType":"column","settings":{"_column_size":100,"_inline_size":null},"elements":[{"id":"94e26c2","elType":"widget","settings":{"anchor":"25"},"elements":[],"widgetType":"menu-anchor"},{"id":"9b7f7d5","elType":"widget","settings":[],"elements":[],"widgetType":"spacer"},{"id":"3cdb29d","elType":"widget","settings":{"image":{"url":"https:\/\/www.collegerealtalk.com\/wp-content\/uploads\/2020\/07\/24-1.jpg","id":2420},"image_size":"medium_large","caption_source":"custom"},"elements":[],"widgetType":"image"},{"id":"74fc300","elType":"widget","settings":{"editor":"

    Same as before. The investments are the same kinds of things as described under the parent section.\u00a0<\/p>","text_color":"#000000","typography_typography":"custom","typography_font_family":"Arial","typography_font_size":{"unit":"px","size":15,"sizes":[]}},"elements":[],"widgetType":"text-editor"}],"isInner":false}],"isInner":false},{"id":"f9daf3c","elType":"section","settings":[],"elements":[{"id":"a59df77","elType":"column","settings":{"_column_size":100,"_inline_size":null},"elements":[{"id":"72f8c52","elType":"widget","settings":{"anchor":"26"},"elements":[],"widgetType":"menu-anchor"},{"id":"c43b96a","elType":"widget","settings":[],"elements":[],"widgetType":"spacer"},{"id":"6b40d06","elType":"widget","settings":{"image":{"url":"https:\/\/www.collegerealtalk.com\/wp-content\/uploads\/2020\/07\/25-1.jpg","id":2421},"image_size":"medium_large","caption_source":"custom"},"elements":[],"widgetType":"image"},{"id":"a14082d","elType":"widget","settings":{"editor":"

    These questions are simple yes or no questions. If you're able to say yes to any of these, kudos to you! I wish I could.<\/p>

    Remember that even if you family owns a farm (or anything else), they asset does not count as the student's unless it is under your name.\u00a0<\/p>","text_color":"#000000","typography_typography":"custom","typography_font_family":"Arial","typography_font_size":{"unit":"px","size":15,"sizes":[]}},"elements":[],"widgetType":"text-editor"}],"isInner":false}],"isInner":false},{"id":"c8a2452","elType":"section","settings":[],"elements":[{"id":"5796cc8","elType":"column","settings":{"_column_size":100,"_inline_size":null},"elements":[{"id":"719a892","elType":"widget","settings":{"anchor":"27"},"elements":[],"widgetType":"menu-anchor"},{"id":"f579370","elType":"widget","settings":[],"elements":[],"widgetType":"spacer"},{"id":"44a35bb","elType":"widget","settings":{"image":{"url":"https:\/\/www.collegerealtalk.com\/wp-content\/uploads\/2020\/07\/26-1.jpg","id":2422},"image_size":"medium_large","caption_source":"custom"},"elements":[],"widgetType":"image"},{"id":"f960dfd","elType":"widget","settings":{"editor":"

    This section is for letting the CSS know about anything that you were unable to convey in your application. If you select any of these options you will be prompted to elaborate in writing. This is the last section before you submit so fill this out if you feel like you are missing something important that could help your case. <\/p>

    Remember the goal of the CSS is to prove to your school that you need more financial aid. If you really believe that you need more aid please submit a full application, and anything that you cannot express in the other questions please elaborate them here!<\/p>","text_color":"#000000","typography_typography":"custom","typography_font_family":"Arial","typography_font_size":{"unit":"px","size":15,"sizes":[]}},"elements":[],"widgetType":"text-editor"}],"isInner":false}],"isInner":false}]

All terms refer to the offer, acceptance and consideration of payment necessary to undertake the process of our assistance to the Client in the most appropriate manner, whether by formal meetings of a fixed duration, or any other means, for the express purpose of meeting the Client's needs in respect of provision of the Company's stated services/products, in accordance with and subject to, prevailing law of United States. Any use of the above terminology or other words in the singular, plural, capitalisation and/or he/she or they, are taken as interchangeable and therefore as referring to same.Cookies We employ the use of cookies. User Comments This Agreement shall begin on the date hereof. item.title: Outside Scholarships
item.dc:creator: qb4htu
item.content:encoded:
Outside Scholarships

Generally, when we are referring to Outside Scholarships we are talking about scholarships that are not federal or school aid. These scholarships are sometimes called private scholarships and can be from a variety of different sources ranging from small companies, large companies, nonprofits, and etc. To give an example the Pell Grant would be consider a federal grant, however the Gates Scholarship, a scholarship funded by Bill Gates, would be an outside scholarship. Another example we would consider an outside scholarship could also be if your high school gave you some money for graduating. This can sometimes be confusing, but the key thing to remember is that Outside scholarships refers to money that is not given to by your college and government, so therefore your old high school counts.  Generally, any money that you get from Outside is money that you have earned from your own efforts and does not need to be paid back. Therefore, students always try to maximize the amount of Outside scholarship that they get because the amount that one can get is solely dependent on ones own effort to win it. However, there are common problems that arise when students apply for Outside Scholarships. In this article, we will be going over these potential problems. Feel free to click on the problems below to go directly to that concern.  These problems are potentially: -WHERE DO I FIND SCHOLARSHIPS? -COLLEGES DEDUCTING AID -STRICT SCHOLARSHIP PAYMENTS -HOW DO YOU WIN SCHOLARSHIPS?

WHERE DO I FIND SCHOLARSHIPS?

One of the most common problems that students immediately run into when trying to apply to outside scholarships is the problem of finding them. Every year there are millions of dollars that are lost in unclaimed scholarships. So one of the goals that a student should have is to not only find a lot of scholarships, but also to find scholarships that have the least amount of people applying to them. Here I have listed the three methods that I personally have used to maximize the total amount of scholarship that I received. There are obviously other ways, but these are just some of mine.  

SCHOLLY

This app has really blown up after its airing on the hit show Shark Tank. Basically the concept of this app is to compile a list of scholarships that are directly targeted for your specific profile. This is a great app to find those scholarships that get untapped.  There is a price tag of about $45 annually, but if you are currently in college I would recommend checking if your school offers you a free Scholly account. It has become more common for schools to offer their students a free Scholly account. If not try to ask your friends if they have free access to it. You are going to want to do this because you already do not have money so, of course, we are going to want to save money in anyway we can! If no one around you has this app, though, it is not a bad investment to make as long as you plan on being dedicated to that scholarship grind.  The key to winning scholarships on this app is to go for the smaller numbers. It is much more likely for you to win 3 scholarships with smaller monetary amounts then it is for you to win a larger scholarship that has the same payout.  Usually students nowadays are lazy and only apply to the large scholarships, but those usually require much more effort and the competition is almost always more intense. 

CORRECT GOOGLE SEARCHES

This option is my favorite way to go about looking for potential scholarships. To do this you need to google: "CompanyName Scholarships." So for example, I would go to google and search up "Amazon scholarships" or even better a company more obscure like "GoPro Scholarship." The reason why I love this method is because you are only limited by the amount of the companies that you know. Nowadays most companies private or public have their own websites and very likely they offer their own scholarships. The big ones like Amazon and Apple will always be on Scholly and other scholarship compilations sites, but the more obscure ones might not be. This is a great process because not only do you get to find potential scholarships, but it is also very unlikely that someone would be searching up the same type of scholarships as you. The scholarships that you will often be very unique and sometimes even fun to complete. For example, the GoPro Scholarship requires you to submit a video. There was even another scholarship I saw a while ago that only required you to input your favorite joke. I recommend that as you do this you make a list of the scholarships that you find so that it will be easier for you to find them next year. 

LOCAL OPTIONS

This option is the most subjective and location based. These are scholarships that are either offered directly by your old high school or a local company in your hometown. These scholarships are usually the easiest to win because you probably know who is giving away this money. You can put a face to the person giving out this money and they can also put a face to you. These local scholarships are why it is super important to build real relationships with the people in your community.  For example, a few years my local pizza store gave out $300 dollars to a recent graduate of my high school. These scholarships are usually paid in cash and therefore are less restrictive with what you can spend them on. These scholarships can sometimes be poorly advertised, meaning they can sometimes lack intense competition.  Most local stores who want to give away money to students of a specific school contact the school's guidance counselor directly. Guidance counselors are usually then diligent enough to then convey that information to the students, but just to be sure always ask your guidance counselor about new scholarship opportunities. You do this so that if they ever hear about one they will be more likely to tell you first. 

COLLEGES DEDUCTING AID

Another common complaint about winning outside scholarship money is that students are afraid that winning scholarships would affect the amount of aid that is granted to them by other means. This is a legitimate complaint that students should have and we would advise each student to understand their own situation. One thing that is pretty universal, though, is that if you win a scholarship and they pay you in a direct deposit you have no obligation to disclose that to your college. Use that money as you please. This problem of colleges deducting money typically arises when the person giving you the scholarship requires a direct deposit towards your college tuition. This of course would immediately verify to the school that you have won a scholarship. If this happens notify whoever is giving you that scholarship and explain to them your situation. It will then be their choice on how to proceed.  It is imperative that you understand your tuition costs and whatnot before you apply for an outside scholarship. Remember these scholarships are not meant for you to use to buy a new Nintendo Switch. They are suppose to be grants to fund your education. If you want to avoid colleges deducting aid the best way would be to aim for the smaller scholarships that pay directly to you. 

STRICT SCHOLARSHIP PAYMENTS

Strict Scholarship payments refer to scholarships that require you to use that money towards a specified list of educational expenses. These list usually restrict the money that you won to only go towards tuition and books & supplies. However, sometimes it is very possible that you might have already paid for these items.  This can be difficult to plan for because it is impractical to plan for winning a scholarship. The key here is then to make sure that you are communicating with the company or person who is giving you your scholarship. If they picked you to win it probably took a long process, therefore do not worry too much that they might give it to someone else. 

HOW DO YOU WIN SCHOLARSHIPS?

The last complaint that students might have is that they are unsure of how to win these scholarships even if they do apply. This a very common problem because most scholarships require some sort of essay writing, which we all know is not commonly celebrated. The solution here then is to be strategic about the type of scholarships that you apply to. One common mistake people make is that they write one essay which they use as a template to apply to a bunch of different scholarships. This strategy is usually very inefficient and honestly a waste of time. You have to remember it is not by purely chance that someone is chosen to win a scholarship. Someone needs to read everyone's essays and if yours is generic it will just be discarded. It is a much better idea write 10 different essays for 10 different scholarships then it is to write 1 for 30 scholarships.  It is also very viable to only search for scholarships that require things other than an essay. There are a lot of scholarships nowadays that require just a video or others that require other works of art.  Lastly,  when you are writing these scholarship essays remember to have fun. It sounds cliche, but it is true. Sometimes there is a reason something is cliche. Take some risks with your writing because the people who will be reading them are not your teachers. They are probably just business people with a lot of money. Try to make them laugh or make them cry, Just write in a way that is enjoyable for you and that shows your awesome unique self! Trust us if you had fun writing your essay it shows! W̶o̶r̶s̶e̶ ̶c̶o̶m̶e̶s̶ ̶t̶o̶ ̶w̶o̶r̶s̶e̶ ̶a̶s̶k̶ ̶y̶o̶u̶r̶ ̶f̶a̶v̶ ̶c̶e̶l̶e̶b̶r̶i̶t̶y̶ ̶t̶o̶ ̶p̶a̶y̶ ̶f̶o̶r̶ ̶y̶o̶u̶r̶ ̶t̶u̶i̶t̶i̶o̶n̶!̶

It is much more likely for you to win 3 scholarships with smaller monetary amounts then it is for you to win a larger scholarship that has the same payout.\u00a0 Usually students nowadays are lazy and only apply to the large scholarships, but those usually require much more effort and the competition is almost always more intense.\u00a0<\/p>","text_color":"#000000","typography_typography":"custom","typography_font_family":"Arial","typography_font_size":{"unit":"px","size":20,"sizes":[]}},"elements":[],"widgetType":"text-editor"},{"id":"9b84357","elType":"widget","settings":{"title":"CORRECT GOOGLE SEARCHES","align":"center","typography_typography":"custom","typography_font_family":"Arial","typography_font_size":{"unit":"px","size":30,"sizes":[]}},"elements":[],"widgetType":"heading"},{"id":"4d7d393","elType":"widget","settings":{"image":{"url":"https:\/\/www.collegerealtalk.com\/wp-content\/uploads\/2020\/07\/GoogleF.jpg","id":2615},"image_size":"thumbnail"},"elements":[],"widgetType":"image"},{"id":"bf8509b","elType":"widget","settings":{"editor":"

This option is my favorite way to go about looking for potential scholarships. To do this you need to google: \"CompanyName<\/span> Scholarships.\" So for example, I would go to google and search up \"Amazon scholarships\" or even better a company more obscure like \"GoPro Scholarship.\"<\/p>

The reason why I love this method is because you are only limited by the amount of the companies that you know. Nowadays most companies private or public have their own websites and very likely they offer their own scholarships. The big ones like Amazon and Apple will always be on Scholly and other scholarship compilations sites, but the more obscure ones might not be.<\/p>

This is a great process because not only do you get to find potential scholarships, but it is also very unlikely that someone would be searching up the same type of scholarships as you. The scholarships that you will often be very unique and sometimes even fun to complete. For example, the GoPro Scholarship requires you to submit a video. There was even another scholarship I saw a while ago that only required you to input your favorite joke. I recommend that as you do this you make a list of the scholarships that you find so that it will be easier for you to find them next year.\u00a0<\/p>","text_color":"#000000","typography_typography":"custom","typography_font_family":"Arial","typography_font_size":{"unit":"px","size":20,"sizes":[]}},"elements":[],"widgetType":"text-editor"},{"id":"0d12db8","elType":"widget","settings":{"title":"LOCAL OPTIONS","align":"center","typography_typography":"custom","typography_font_family":"Arial","typography_font_size":{"unit":"px","size":30,"sizes":[]}},"elements":[],"widgetType":"heading"},{"id":"9d77cd5","elType":"widget","settings":{"image":{"url":"https:\/\/www.collegerealtalk.com\/wp-content\/uploads\/2020\/07\/Local-1.png","id":2617},"image_size":"medium"},"elements":[],"widgetType":"image"},{"id":"15d68c0","elType":"widget","settings":{"editor":"

This option is the most subjective and location based. These are scholarships that are either offered directly by your old high school or a local company in your hometown. These scholarships are usually the easiest to win because you probably know who is giving away this money. You can put a face to the person giving out this money and they can also put a face to you. These local scholarships are why it is super important to build real relationships with the people in your community.\u00a0<\/p>

For example, a few years my local pizza store gave out $300 dollars to a recent graduate of my high school. These scholarships are usually paid in cash and therefore are less restrictive with what you can spend them on. These scholarships can sometimes be poorly advertised, meaning they can sometimes lack intense competition.\u00a0<\/p>

Most local stores who want to give away money to students of a specific school contact the school's guidance counselor directly. Guidance counselors are usually then diligent enough to then convey that information to the students, but just to be sure always ask your guidance counselor about new scholarship opportunities. You do this so that if they ever hear about one they will be more likely to tell you first.\u00a0<\/p>","text_color":"#000000","typography_typography":"custom","typography_font_family":"Arial","typography_font_size":{"unit":"px","size":20,"sizes":[]}},"elements":[],"widgetType":"text-editor"}],"isInner":false}],"isInner":false},{"id":"6ad9ffb","elType":"section","settings":[],"elements":[{"id":"685d0ab","elType":"column","settings":{"_column_size":100,"_inline_size":null},"elements":[{"id":"9b602c6","elType":"widget","settings":{"anchor":"2"},"elements":[],"widgetType":"menu-anchor"},{"id":"49849e5","elType":"widget","settings":[],"elements":[],"widgetType":"spacer"},{"id":"f456ec0","elType":"widget","settings":{"title":"COLLEGES DEDUCTING AID","align":"center","typography_typography":"custom","typography_font_family":"Arial","typography_font_size":{"unit":"px","size":40,"sizes":[]}},"elements":[],"widgetType":"heading"},{"id":"f5c3454","elType":"widget","settings":{"image":{"url":"https:\/\/www.collegerealtalk.com\/wp-content\/uploads\/2020\/07\/HDU.jpg","id":2618},"image_size":"medium"},"elements":[],"widgetType":"image"},{"id":"1663080","elType":"widget","settings":{"editor":"

Another common complaint about winning outside scholarship money is that students are afraid that winning scholarships would affect the amount of aid that is granted to them by other means. This is a legitimate complaint that students should have and we would advise each student to understand their own situation. One thing that is pretty universal, though, is that if you win a scholarship and they pay you in a direct deposit you have no obligation to disclose that to your college. Use that money as you please.<\/p>

This problem of colleges deducting money typically arises when the person giving you the scholarship requires a direct deposit towards your college tuition. This of course would immediately verify to the school that you have won a scholarship. If this happens notify whoever is giving you that scholarship and explain to them your situation. It will then be their choice on how to proceed.\u00a0<\/p>

It is imperative that you understand your tuition costs and whatnot before you apply for an outside scholarship. Remember these scholarships are not meant for you to use to buy a new Nintendo Switch. They are suppose to be grants to fund your education.\u00a0If you want to avoid colleges deducting aid the best way would be to aim for the smaller scholarships that pay directly to you.\u00a0<\/p>","text_color":"#000000","typography_typography":"custom","typography_font_family":"Arial","typography_font_size":{"unit":"px","size":20,"sizes":[]}},"elements":[],"widgetType":"text-editor"}],"isInner":false}],"isInner":false},{"id":"6f0d57e","elType":"section","settings":[],"elements":[{"id":"6ae8c08","elType":"column","settings":{"_column_size":100,"_inline_size":null},"elements":[{"id":"7011d2f","elType":"widget","settings":{"anchor":"3"},"elements":[],"widgetType":"menu-anchor"},{"id":"d9d89ac","elType":"widget","settings":{"title":"STRICT SCHOLARSHIP PAYMENTS","align":"center","typography_typography":"custom","typography_font_family":"Arial","typography_font_size":{"unit":"px","size":40,"sizes":[]}},"elements":[],"widgetType":"heading"},{"id":"3081b23","elType":"widget","settings":[],"elements":[],"widgetType":"spacer"},{"id":"18f4123","elType":"widget","settings":{"image":{"url":"https:\/\/www.collegerealtalk.com\/wp-content\/uploads\/2020\/07\/MyMoney.jpg","id":2619},"image_size":"medium"},"elements":[],"widgetType":"image"},{"id":"69a1648","elType":"widget","settings":{"editor":"

Strict Scholarship payments refer to scholarships that require you to use that money towards a specified list of educational expenses. These list usually restrict the money that you won to only go towards tuition and books & supplies. However, sometimes it is very possible that you might have already paid for these items.\u00a0<\/p>

This can be difficult to plan for because it is impractical to plan for winning a scholarship. The key here is then to make sure that you are communicating with the company or person who is giving you your scholarship. If they picked you to win it probably took a long process, therefore do not worry too much that they might give it to someone else.\u00a0<\/p>","text_color":"#000000","typography_typography":"custom","typography_font_family":"Arial","typography_font_size":{"unit":"px","size":20,"sizes":[]}},"elements":[],"widgetType":"text-editor"}],"isInner":false}],"isInner":false},{"id":"8a4e287","elType":"section","settings":[],"elements":[{"id":"56b17ed","elType":"column","settings":{"_column_size":100,"_inline_size":null},"elements":[{"id":"9a5900e","elType":"widget","settings":[],"elements":[],"widgetType":"menu-anchor"},{"id":"7842592","elType":"widget","settings":[],"elements":[],"widgetType":"spacer"},{"id":"486ff12","elType":"widget","settings":{"title":"HOW DO YOU WIN SCHOLARSHIPS?","align":"center","typography_typography":"custom","typography_font_family":"Arial","typography_font_size":{"unit":"px","size":40,"sizes":[]}},"elements":[],"widgetType":"heading"},{"id":"557f6b6","elType":"widget","settings":{"image":{"url":"https:\/\/www.collegerealtalk.com\/wp-content\/uploads\/2020\/07\/Yourself.png","id":2620},"image_size":"thumbnail"},"elements":[],"widgetType":"image"},{"id":"a1d27f7","elType":"widget","settings":{"editor":"

The last complaint that students might have is that they are unsure of how to win these scholarships even if they do apply. This a very common problem because most scholarships require some sort of essay writing, which we all know is not commonly celebrated.<\/p>

The solution here then is to be strategic about the type of scholarships that you apply to. One common mistake people make is that they write one essay which they use as a template to apply to a bunch of different scholarships. This strategy is usually very inefficient and honestly a waste of time. You have to remember it is not by purely chance that someone is chosen to win a scholarship. Someone needs to read everyone's essays and if yours is generic it will just be discarded. It is a much better idea write 10 different essays for 10 different scholarships then it is to write 1 for 30 scholarships.\u00a0<\/p>

It is also very viable to only search for scholarships that require things other than an essay. There are a lot of scholarships nowadays that require just a video or others that require other works of art.\u00a0<\/p>

Lastly,\u00a0 when you are writing these scholarship essays remember to have fun. It sounds cliche, but it is true. Sometimes there is a reason something is cliche. Take some risks with your writing because the people who will be reading them are not your teachers. They are probably just business people with a lot of money. Try to make them laugh or make them cry, Just write in a way that is enjoyable for you and that shows your awesome unique self! Trust us if you had fun writing your essay it shows!<\/p>

W\u0336o\u0336r\u0336s\u0336e\u0336 \u0336c\u0336o\u0336m\u0336e\u0336s\u0336 \u0336t\u0336o\u0336 \u0336w\u0336o\u0336r\u0336s\u0336e\u0336 \u0336a\u0336s\u0336k\u0336 \u0336y\u0336o\u0336u\u0336r\u0336 \u0336f\u0336a\u0336v\u0336 \u0336c\u0336e\u0336l\u0336e\u0336b\u0336r\u0336i\u0336t\u0336y\u0336 \u0336t\u0336o\u0336 \u0336p\u0336a\u0336y\u0336 \u0336f\u0336o\u0336r\u0336 \u0336y\u0336o\u0336u\u0336r\u0336 \u0336t\u0336u\u0336i\u0336t\u0336i\u0336o\u0336n\u0336!\u0336<\/p>","text_color":"#000000","typography_typography":"custom","typography_font_family":"Arial","typography_font_size":{"unit":"px","size":20,"sizes":[]}},"elements":[],"widgetType":"text-editor"}],"isInner":false}],"isInner":false}]

item.title: About Us
item.dc:creator: qb4htu
item.content:encoded:
So, Real Talk

Figuring out what to do with your future is tough. As a kid, you think you know some things and know there’s a Costco’s Isle worth of things you don’t. We’ve been there, done that – and are here to help.

Your guidance counselor may be telling you to apply to nearby four year schools. Nobody talks much about why Community College might be a smart move and we’re sure you’ve never even heard of Trade School. All you know about College is that it’s expensive, some are more respected than others, and you’re under a lot of pressure to attend the best school you can get into. If you’re not in the top 1% of students, you may end up applying to your dream school and a few local universities.

Do you know what the campus culture is like? Do the professors care about the students? Are there a lot of parties? Are the buildings well kept? Do Freshmen have to dorm? How will you get around? Can you keep proper diet and exercise?

Do you know if the school offers what you want and need? How competitive are the academics? Is the curriculum actually what I want to learn for my Major? How are classes graded? Does the school care about mental health / disabilities?

We made this site to help people make informed decisions about their future- I mean, you have your whole life ahead of you! Make the best decisions for YOU, get knowledgeable about schools, and go live YOUR best life.
